Living Wages,' Fewer Jobs
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City is trying to repeal the law of supply and demand. A bill supported by a majority of City Council members would require companies with city contracts to pay their employees a minimum of $12.10 an hour. The proposal, which proponents call "living wage" legislation, would do to the labor market what rent control has done to the housing market: drive up prices and destroy opportunities for the poor.

Journal;The Capital Gang
How To Save Children
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Prompted by the death of 6-year-old Elisa lzquierdo, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is revamping the New York City agency that handles child abuse. At the same time, legislation to lift the veil of secrecy from child abuse cases -- by authorizing the release of confidential agency information -- is on a fast track in Albany. Both changes should make the workings of the child welfare system more visible and thus help the public understand why so many Elisas are left in dangerous homes. 

     The real villain is neither slothful caseworkers nor budget cuts, although they have hurt. It is society's unwillingness to deal with the simple fact that  crack addicts make terrible parents. That failure is why Elisa, sexually abused  and tortured, was found beaten to death in November and her mother is charged with murder.

At Yale, a Decent Life Is a Radical Idea
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The first baby-boomer administration at Yale is reliving its radical youth -- but this time as the Establishment. 

     On Wednesday, 137 protesters were arrested on the campus for civil disobedience. This unrest is the latest episode in a five-year battle between the administration and the Graduate Employees and Students Organization, which is seeking to unionize the university's graduate students.

MUSIC REVIEW;Evening Devoted to Debussy
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Syrinx," Debussy's haunting meditation for solo flute, is not a work you expect to encounter at an orchestral concert. But on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, with the rest of the New York Philharmonic seated in darkness, there was the orchestra's principal flutist, Jeanne Baxtresser, in her normal place, gently lit, opening this week's mostly Debussy program by herself. 

     It proved a wonderful way to focus the audience's attention. But Kurt Masur,  who conducted, is also fond of programming pieces that connect audibly. And as soon as he began the "Prelude a l'Apres-Midi d'un Faune" (1892-94), there was Ms. Baxtresser again, with the languid flute solos out of which "Syrinx" evolved in 1913.
